facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 167 of 1964 was filed in the Supreme Court's Criminal Appellate Jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No . 167 of 1964.

facts.text: The appeal is from the judgment and order dated November 4, 1963 of the Gujarat High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 734 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order November 4, 1963 of the Gujarat High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 734 of 1962.

facts.text: S. Patwardhan, R. N. Sachthey and B.R.G.K. Achar appeared for the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: S. Patwardhan, R. N. Sachthey and B.R.G.K. Achar, for the appellant.

facts.text: The respondent did not appear.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent did number appear.

facts.text: The judgment of the Supreme Court was delivered by Ramaswami, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Ramaswami, J.

facts.text: State of Gujarat brought the appeal against the Gujarat High Court judgment dated November 4, 1963 in Criminal Appeal No. 734 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is brought by the State of Gujarat against the judgment of the High Court of Gujarat at Ahmeda- bad dated November 4, 1963 in Criminal Appeal No. 734 of 1962.

facts.text: The respondent was charged in the Court of the Judicial Magistrate First Class, Bulsar under sections 4 and 5 of the Bombay Prevention of Gambling Act, 1887 (Bombay Act IV of 1887).

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was charged in the Court of the Judicial Magistrate First Class, Bulsar under ss. 4 and 5 of the Bombay Prevention of Gambling Act, 1887  Bombay Act IV of 1887 , hereinafter called the Act.

facts.text: On January 31, 1962 at about 9 p.m., the respondent was found accepting bets on American futures.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the prosecution was that on January 31, 1962 at about 9 p.m. the respondent was found accepting bets on American futures.

facts.text: Upon search in the presence of panchas, currency notes of Rs. 119/- and two slips recording American futures were found from the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: On being searched in the presence of panchas currency numberes of Rs. 119/- and two slips on which Ameri-can futures were recorded were found.

facts.text: The trying Magistrate held that the slips were not instruments of gaming within the meaning of section 7 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The trying Magistrate, however, held that slips were number instruments of gaming within ,the meaning of s. 7 of the Act.

facts.text: The Magistrate was not satisfied that the police officer who carried out the search and seized the articles had reasonable grounds to believe that the slips and articles were instruments of gaming.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate was also number satisfied that the police officer who carried out the search and .seized the articles had reasonable grounds to believe that the slips and other articles recovered from the respondent were instruments of gaming.

facts.text: The Magistrate held that the presumption under section 7 of the Act could not be raised.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate held that the presumption under s. 7 of the Act companyld number be raised.

facts.text: The respondent was acquitted of the charge by the Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was, therefore, acquitted of the charge.

facts.text: State of Gujarat preferred an appeal against the acquittal order to the High Court of Gujarat at Ahmedabad in Criminal Appeal No. 734 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Against the order of acquittal the State of Gujarat preferred an appeal to the High Court of Gujarat at Ahmedabad in Criminal Appeal No. 734 of 1962.

facts.text: The High Court appeal was dismissed by Raju, J. on November 4, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal was dismissed by Raju, J. on November 4, 1963.

facts.text: Mr. Patwardhan submitted that the High Court erred in holding that an expert was necessary to corroborate the Sub-Inspector's evidence on instruments of gaming.

anchor.surface_text: In support of this appeal Mr. Patwardhan submitted that the High Court was in error in holding that it is necessary to examine an expert to companyroborate the evidence of the prosecuting Sub-Inspector that the articles seized were instruments of gaming.

facts.text: Counsel contended that the High Court was not right in viewing that the Police Inspector's evidence required corroboration in every case.

anchor.surface_text: It was also companytended by Counsel that the High Court was number right in taking the view that the evidence of the Police Inspector to whom the warrant was issued under s. 6 of the Act required companyroboration in each and every case.

facts.text: The Supreme Court held that both contentions of Mr. Patwardhan are well-founded.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, both the companytentions of Mr. Patwardhan are well-founded and must be

facts.text: There is nothing in the Act suggesting prosecution must examine an expert in every case to prove instruments of gaming.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberhing in the Act to suggest that in order to prove that the articles seized are instruments of gaming it is the duty of the prosecution to examine an expert in every case.

facts.text: The Supreme Court does not propose to interfere with the order of acquittal because the offence is petty and was committed several years back.

anchor.surface_text: We do number, however, propose to interfere with the order of acquittal in this case, because the offence is petty and the offence was companymitted several years back.

facts.text: The search was carried out by a police officer.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate was also number satisfied that the police officer who carried out the search and .seized the articles had reasonable grounds to believe that the slips and other articles recovered from the respondent were instruments of gaming.

facts.text: The warrant was issued under section 6 of the Act to the Police Inspector.

anchor.surface_text: It was also companytended by Counsel that the High Court was number right in taking the view that the evidence of the Police Inspector to whom the warrant was issued under s. 6 of the Act required companyroboration in each and every case.

facts.text: Articles seized included currency notes and slips.

anchor.surface_text: On being searched in the presence of panchas currency numberes of Rs. 119/- and two slips on which Ameri-can futures were recorded were found.

facts.text: The High Court of Gujarat is located at Ahmedabad.

anchor.surface_text: Against the order of acquittal the State of Gujarat preferred an appeal to the High Court of Gujarat at Ahmedabad in Criminal Appeal No. 734 of 1962.

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 6 Bombay Prevention of Gambling Act
concepts.unlisted_description: Entry, search, seizure in gaming houses; warrant to police

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 of the Act defines the expression instruments of gaming as including any article used or intended to be used as a subject or means of gaming, any document used or intended to be used as a register or record or evidence of any gaming, the proceeds of any gaming, and any winnings or prizes in money or ,otherwise distributed or intended to be distributed in respect of ,any gaming.

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 3 Bombay Prevention of Gambling Act

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 provides for entry and search by police officers in gaming houses. Section 6 1  states 6.  1  It shall be lawful for a Police Officer- in any area for which a Commissioner of Police has been appointed number below the rank of a Sub-Inspector and either empowered by general order in writing or authorized in each case by special warrant issued by the Commissioner of Police, and elsewhere number below the rank of a Sub-Inspector of Police authorised by special warrant issued in each case by a District Magistrate or Sub-Divisional Magistrate or by a Taluka Magistrate specially empowered by the State Government in this behalf or by a Superintendent of Police or by an Assistant or Deputy Superintendent of Police especially empowered by the State Government in this behalf, and without prejudice to the provision in clause  ii  above, in such other area as the State Government may, by numberification in the Official Gazette, specify in this behalf, number below the rank of a Sub-Inspector and empowered by general order in writing issued by the District Magistrate.

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 6 Bombay Prevention of Gambling Act
concepts.unlisted_description: Powers of police for entry and search

anchor.surface_text: Section 7 of the Act relates to presumptive proof of keeping or gaming in companymon gaming-house. Section 7 provides as follows When any instrument of gaming has been seized in any house, room or place entered under section 6 or about the person of anyone found therein, and in the case of any other thing so seized if the companyrt is satisfied that the Police officer who entered such house, room or place had reasonable grounds for suspecting that the thing so seized was an instrument of gaming, the seizure of such instrument or thing shall be evidence, until the companytrary is proved, that such house, room or place is used as a companymon gaming-house and the persons found therein were then present for the purpose of gaming, although numbergaming was actually seen by the Magistrate or the Police officer or by any person acting under the authority of either of them

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 7 Bombay Prevention of Gambling Act

concepts.interpretation: Prosecution not required to examine expert in every case to prove articles are instruments of gaming; can be proved by proper evidence

arguments.claim: Whether evidence of person executing warrant requires corroboration depends on facts and circumstances of each case, no legal distinction merely because they made the complaint

anchor.surface_text: The question as to whether the evidence of the person who executes the warrant requires companyroboration depends on the facts and circumstances of each case and numberlegal distinction can be made merely because the person who executes the warrant happens to be the person who makes the companyplaint under the proviso to s. 6 of the Act to the Commissioner of Police or to the Magistrate.

holdings.text: both the contentions of Mr. Patwardhan are well-founded and must be

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, both the companytentions of Mr. Patwardhan are well-founded and must be

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court agrees with petitioner's arguments against High Court's requirements on expert evidence and corroboration.

holdings.text: There is nothing in the Act to suggest that in order to prove that the articles seized are instruments of gaming it is the duty of the prosecution to examine an expert in every case.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberhing in the Act to suggest that in order to prove that the articles seized are instruments of gaming it is the duty of the prosecution to examine an expert in every case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of the Act shows no such mandatory requirement; prosecution can use proper evidence.

holdings.text: It is open to the prosecution to prove that the articles seized are instruments of gaming by proper evidence and it is, not necessary to examine an expert for the purpose in each and every case.

anchor.surface_text: It is open to the prosecution to prove that the articles seized are instruments of gaming by proper evidence and it is, number necessary to examine an expert for the purpose in each and every case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proof can be by appropriate evidence without expert in every instance.

holdings.text: It is also not proper to make a distinction between the evidence of an officer who makes a complaint under the proviso to s. 6 of the Act and to whom a warrant is issued for search and the evidence of a person to whom a warrant is issued but who makes no such complaint under the proviso.

anchor.surface_text: It is also number proper to make a distinction between the evidence of an officer who makes a companyplaint under the proviso to s. 6 of the Act and to whom a warrant is issued for search and the evidence of a person to whom a warrant is issued but who makes numbersuch companyplaint under the proviso.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No legal basis for distinguishing based on whether the officer filed the complaint.

holdings.text: The question as to whether the evidence of the person who executes the warrant requires corroboration depends on the facts and circumstances of each case and no legal distinction can be made merely because the person who executes the warrant happens to be the person who makes the complaint under the proviso to s. 6 of the Act to the Commissioner of Police or to the Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: The question as to whether the evidence of the person who executes the warrant requires companyroboration depends on the facts and circumstances of each case and numberlegal distinction can be made merely because the person who executes the warrant happens to be the person who makes the companyplaint under the proviso to s. 6 of the Act to the Commissioner of Police or to the Magistrate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Corroboration need assessed case-by-case, not mandatorily or based on complaint role.

holdings.text: We do not, however, propose to interfere with the order of acquittal in this case, because the offence is petty and the offence was committed several years back.

anchor.surface_text: We do number, however, propose to interfere with the order of acquittal in this case, because the offence is petty and the offence was companymitted several years back.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Discretionary non-interference due to trivial nature of offence and passage of time.

anchor.surface_text: We do number, however, propose to interfere with the order of acquittal in this case, because the offence is petty and the offence was companymitted several years back.

outcome.relief_summary: Court does not propose to interfere with the order of acquittal
